div.head: Cyprus Government Railway.
div.p: The Limassol S.S. Co. steamers with good passenger accommodation run between Cyprus & Egypt as follows:—

Trains run alongside the steamers on the quay, and passengers can be conveyed to Famagusta, Nicosia, Morphou and intermediate stations. Good hotel accommodation for tourists is provided at Famagusta, at the Savoy Hotel (Mr. Najem Houry proprietor). Olympus Hotel, Mount Troodos, 6000 ft. above the sea. Magnificent Scenery. Perfect climate. Season May to end of October. For information apply to Mr. Najem Houry, Managing Director of Cyprus Hotel Co., Army Contractor, Limassol, Cyprus. There is a good carriage road from Kopia (on Railway) to Troodos. At Famagusta may be seen the fine old Latin Cathedral (now a mosque) begun in 1300 and finished in 1312, together with other ancient ruins and the Venetian fortifications, the finest in the world. Also the tower or palace, the scene of "Othello'' and of Ford's "Lover's Melancholy.'' The climate of Cyprus in the winter months is delightful and the Island will well repay a visit.
Information as to tickets, trains, etc., may be obtained of Messrs. Thomas Cook & Son, Egypt, or from the General Manager Railways, Famagusta. G. BERT DAY, General Manager. 29248—31-12-907

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: The General Assembly.
div.p: The "Times," in an article on th eproposals of the General Assembly, remarks :- "These proposals, it will be observed, form a part of the Nationalist programme of which we pub- lished a smmary on Saturday. They are the work of the same party who only last year were anxious to restore the authority of the Sultan in Egypt, and who did their utmost to stir up an anti-British movement in his favour at the time of the Akabah incident. Had they succeeded in their designs they would hardly have enjoyed any great meausre of Parliamentary liberties. Doubtless they would not even have asked for anything of the kind. They would have attained their real oject, which is a return to the old system of class privlege, oppression and corruption, and attained it in the most direct and effective way. As they were baffled in their attempts to gain it directly, they are now seeking to gain it, or, at any rate, to prepare the way for gaining is, with the great majority of them, the mean- ing of their sudden devotion to the cause of constitutional freedom. They are the men who intrigued with the French, so long as they had any hope that the Fench would help them to get rid of the honest and oderly administra- tion which they hate. Now that they have had to renounce all hopes of that kind, and that their efforts to provoke the intervention of the Turks have lamentably failed, they are seek- ing to play upon the weaknesses of extreme British Radicalism by posing as the champions of Nationalism and of Parliamentary govern- ment"

In view of the recent demands by the General Assembly for a Parliament the follow- ing views on native self-government in India written by General John Jacob, of Sind, in 1854, may interest our readers at this juncture. They occur in a book entitled "Views and Opi- nions of Brigadier-General John Jacob," publish- ed by Smith, Taylor and Co., Bombay, 1858: To the Anglo-Saxon race self-governemnt is essential. But force the Oriental to take his share in government, and you will soon have no government at all. The former considers that which unnecessarily interferes with his freedom to be wrong, and thinks and acts upon the principle that all men have equal rights. The latter considers being compelled to govern hiumself as the greatest oppresion and tyranny. He expects to be ruled, and to be ruled well; otherwise he will, perhaps rebel and destroy his bad rulers. But in no case will he attempt to establish freedome. It is obvious that the two races of men with princples of action and feelings different, can never be successfully managed by adpoting one system, and forcing it alike on both. But while incapable of self- governemnt, the natives of India, like-other

human beings, feel gratitude and devotion towards those who raise their moral, intellec- ual, and social position; and are actuated by a strong wish and earnest zeal to show that they are worthy of the respectable position to which they are raised. Too mistrustful of their equals to submit to their rule, cheerfully sub- mit to an English gentleman, whom they all acknowledge and feel to be their superior. We hold India, then, by being in reality, as in reputation, a superior race to teh Asiatic; and if this natral superiority did not exist, we should not, and could not, retain the country for one week. If, then, we really are a morally superior race, governed by higher motives, and possessing higher attribtes than the Asiatics, the more the natives of India are able to understand us, and the more we improve their capacity for so understanding, the firmer will become our power. Away, then, with the assumption of equalityl and let us accept our true position of a dominant race. So placed, let s establish our rule by setting them a high example, by making them feel the value of truth and honesty, and by raising their moral and intellectal powers. But if we are not superior to the Indians, the attempt to retain our soverignty over the will be as hopeles,. as it will be vicious. And England neither can nor wishes to be powerful in evil.
Egyptian NAtionalists and the French Press

Notwithstanding the sparse sympathy they have receied from the French press in their campaign the Egyptian Nationalists, through Kamel Pasha, continue their efforts to obtain the support of the French people for the "cause." The "Depeche Coloniale" has received from M Said Aly "le veritable programme du parti national Egyptien," accompanied by a request for insertion. After giving the principal passages of the documents the "Depeche Co- loniale" makes some wholesome reflections on the NAtionalist movement of scarcely an en- couraging nature. The writer points out that Egypt can only expect its liberation by means of intellectual progress. He repeats what has been said before in the "Depeche Coloniale"- namely, that England has inspired capitalists with confidence and attracted them to the Valley of the Nile, first, by consolidating the political situtation secondly, by establishing order in the Administration and finances ; thirdly, by undertaking great works of public utility for commerce and agriculture. The writer, Dr. George Samne, proceeds to observe that to form an impartial judgement of the part played by England in Egypt it is suf- ficient to recall the financial difficulties which Egypt had to face 25 years ago. The situation at the time of the establishment of the Franco- British Condominium and the desposition of the Khedive Ismail must be borne in mind. An edifying example of what Egyptian Viceroyalty could do was seen under Ismail's rule. There are two kinds of tutleage for a people. If it requires a tutor because it is not yet educated and is too young to get on a one, there is no dishonour for it to accept advice and support. That seems to the "Depeche Coloniale" to be the case of the Egypt of to-day, which can derive advantage from England to become worthy of its emancipation.

div.head: Bubonic Plague.
div.p: Yesterday's plague bulletin reports one ce at Tahta and Deirout, 5 cases and 3 deaths hospital at Baliana, 2 cases and 2 deaths hospital at Akhmim, where one death ontsi hospital is also recorded. Thirty persons remain under treatment.

div.head: Electricity at Khartoum.
div.p: The electric light installation for Khartoum will be delivered to the Sudan Public Work Department at the end of this month. Ti price of the supply will be moderate. Express in non-technical language it works out about P.T. 150 for a good-sized flat.

div.head: Pattie Plague.
div.p: Plague has appeared among the cattle Mellawi, where the fellaheen are reported have displayed an unusual disregard of ti regulations of the Public Health Department The Sanitary authorities are now taking vigorous measures to check this negligence.

div.head: Grand Concert
div.p: The celebrated German pianist Herr Koel ler, a pupil of Liszt and von Bulow, will give grand concert on Saturday at the Savoy Palace Hotel. The programme is very varied a comprises the principal works of Handel Beethoven, Schubert, Mendelssohn, Chopin, Liszt, and Wagner.

div.head: Creek Institutions.
div.p: On the 25th March (Old Style), 8th April (New Style), which is the anniversary of the Declaration of Greek Independence, the foundation stone will be laid of Mr. Benachi's Greek Orphanage and Mr. George Zervudachi's Greek Elementary School at Chatby The architect is Mr. George Lezinas and the contractor Mr Diamante.

div.head: Cambridge Dramatic Society.
div.p: Cambridge University is about to establish a French dramatic society. Everywhere and every day it becomes more of an absolute necessity to know several modern languages The 335 Berlitz schools answer to this urgent and general need.
Their schools in Alexandria and Cairo are amongst the most prosperous.
The teaching is given exactly in the Berlitz method known by all the world as the best for learning both quickly and well.

div.head: Al Gerida
div.p: We have received the first and second numbers of "Al-Gerida" (The Journal), the new national organ published in Cairo by a company composed of members of the Legislative Council and a number of other native notables, under the presidency of Mahmoud Pasha Suleiman.
The first issue of "Al-Gerida" appeared on Saturday last and consists of six pages. The Editor, Ahmed Bey Lutfy El-Sayid, in a leading article, enunciates the paper's policy and aims.
The new organ publishes a long article on"Patriotism," an article dealing with financial and social points of comparison between the United States and Egypt, eto, etc.

div.head: THREATENED MUTINY AT SUEZ
div.p: TURKISH TROOPS GIVE TROUBLE.
(From OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Suez, Monday.

Two Turkish troopships arrived from Hodeidah yesterday, i.e., the Hodeidah and Taif. The Taif put into Tor in order to perform the usual quarantine, but the troops op board mutinied and compelled the Captain to bring them to Suez, which was done. On arrival the quarantine authorities ordered the hip to return to Tor, but the trops refuse o go, and want to go instantly through the anal, otherwise they threaten trouble. I understand that the authorities are in communication with the Quarantine Board in Alexandria in order to obtain permission for the ship to go through the Canal. In the meantime, the ship is guarded by a Coast Guard steam launch
Later. The Taif entered the Canal in quarantine his afternoon in order to avoid a mutiny.

div.head: "THE EGYPT OF THE FUTURE."
div.p: The Cairo correspondent of the "Pall Mall Gazette" makes the following remarks on Mr. Dicey's book The Egypt of the Future" :-

There is one point on which I think all right-minded residents agree-and that is that the publication of Mr. Dicey's book was most injudicious. Criticism is excellent ; it Gives guests to all enterprises, and contributes ne of the rights which Englishmen consider their very own. But criticism can only be healthy, when it is made at an auspicious moment-and I do not think any one can main- tain with success that the present is the fitting moment to di-cuss the methods adopted by word Cromer and attack his projects. Mr. icey would not like to be classed with the Little Englanders—in fact, from his writings me would consider him essentially an Imperialist-yet "Egypt of the Future" will, I am afraid, have the same effect as any publication of the Little Englander Press. It is being read with avidity by the natives--within less than a week an educated Egyptian told me he had read it in Arabic-and one can rest assured that the portions deprecating the British policy and methods will be enlarged upon.

The present is a critical time for Egypt, and no matter how sincerely and deeply one may el on the question, and no matter how authoritatively one can write on the subject, the best course is an unselfish one, i.e., to keep one's criticisms out of print and from the reach of those who will make unfair capital out of them Mr. Dicey, although his style and experience command every respect and attention, could not possibly have expected that his criticisms and proposals would be adopted in reference to the present British Agent's projects, and so the only effect, if any, they could have, would be that of rendering it more difficult. alt for the latter to conciliate the malcontents and carry on his work in Egypt.

div.head: THE CAIRO HAMMAM.
DISAPPEARANCE OF LANDMARK.
div.p: Residents as well as tourists will, we feel sure, be sorry to learn that the fine establishment in the Halim Square, Cairo, is to be closed on the 1st April. The lease held by the proprietors, Messrs. Fornario and Rossi, has not expired, but as they were offered an indemnity to cede the premises, these gentlemen decided to accept the offer with the intention of erecting author Hammam when they are able to secure another suitable and central site.
The establishment, which is fitted with the latest improvements and includes electrical and every other description of batha, has been very largely patronised since its inauguration in 1901.

It is stated that the site is required for the erection of a first-class musio-hall and that a very advantageous offer has been made for its acquisition to the Societé Belge Egyptienne de l'Esbekieh, the present owners.

div.head: EGYPTIAN IMPROVEMENTS CORPORATION.
div.p: The ordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Egyptian Improvements Corporation was held on Saturday last at the Continental Hotel, Cairo, 16,186 shares being represented. The report of the directors and the profit and loss account were approved, and it was decided to pay a dividend of P.T. 70 per share, or 20 per cent. on the amount paid up.

div.head: OPERA HOUSE STRIKE
CHORUS PREVENT PERFORMANCE
div.p: Another strike has to be reported at the Khedivial Opera House, Cairo. The Catholic Charitable Society was to benefit from a performance of "Herodiade" last night, but at 8.45 p.m., just as the curtain was about to be raised, a member of the chorus appeared to ir form M Poncet that unless he consented to pay them the total grant of 2,500 francs which ho had promised, they would not sing. M Poncet declined on the ground that under the agreement concluded before the French Consul on November 26, 1906, it was stipulated that the surplus allowance should be granted to the chorus if M. Poncet had reason to be satisfied with their conduct. He proposed to continue without the chorus when the orchestra struck and the performance was rendered impossible

M. Poncet complained to the French Consulate, with the result that an individual who had inspired this breach of contract on the part of the chorus found himself in the hands of a consular cavass. He resisted, however, and finally made good his escape--for the time at least. If captured he will be tried, for resistance to a public functionary during the execution of his duties.

div.head: "LA REINE FIAMETTE."
div.p: I confess I cannot join in the transports e roked in two English colleagues by "La Reine Fiametto." The poet and the music have both exquisite moments and a certain uniform charm of rhythm and construction ; but there is a certain lack of conviction; there are wearisome passages, long monologues of declamation, and what struck me most was the almost 'inseparable presence of violence and beauty all through the whole subject. This, it may be said, was the essence of the days the poem treats Yes ; but the stories that show those dıys are episodes, histories, anything—but not poems. I cannot but feel that the charm legendary, pastoral, faëry almost-should have been to the fore all through, and the horror in the background,--the plain, flowerclad, where are the maidens, should be sunlit, ringed, if you will, by distant mountains over which gither clouds to the faint, ominous sounds of thunder. Perhaps this is extravagance, but the whole play should have been one delicious extravagance, without such grim human reminder of cruelty-loving cardinals and weak, evil king-consorts.

As to the performance, M. Archambault has a: last tamed his orchestra, and his quiet skill pas certainly conspicuous all through. Mlle Charpentier was far better than usual, both in singing and acting. M. Fontaine acted well enough, båt the long monologues showed, futally, the distasteful strangled utterance which he scarcely ever seems to shake off. Mlle I evilloy was as perfect as ever ; each note was a delight in itself. Mlle Karl had only one song in the 2nd act-and in that she was unusually good, better, perhaps, than she has been the whole season. M Lorec was most disappointing : he so often sings charmingly, with some slight mannerism, it is true, but with real taste. He was discordant, harsh, and scarcely ever true to the note. The others one need not notice over much. On the whole, it gave me the impression I have of the opera and poem itself—some charming moments in a disappointing evening.

div.head: BRITISH CHAMBER OF COMMERCE.
div.p: A meeting of the British Chamber of ComMerce was held yesterday for the purpose of electing office-bearers for the ensuing year. Mr. S.H. Carver was elected president in lieu of Mr. H.P. Kingham, whose term of office expired; Mr. R. Lang Anderson, vice-president, in lieu of Mr. A. A. Ralli, whose term of office expired, and Mr. R. C. Abdy hon. Treasurer, in lieu of Mr. H. E Barker, whose term of office likewise expired. Mr. A 8 Preston was, elected hon. legal adviser and Messrs. Russell, Kerr and Wyatt hon. auditors for the current year. A hearty vote of thanks to the retiring president and vice-president concluded the proceedings.

FATAL SHOOTING EXCURSION.
div.p: M. Grandmoulin; of the Legal Bureau in the Ministry of Finance, and ex-director of the Khedivial Law School, Cairo, was out shooting on Friday afternoon in a corn field between Matarieh and Marg, near Cairo, when a son of the owner of the land, aged 13, appeared and attempted to prevent M. Grandmoul n from continuing his sport. The latter, however, paid little heed to the boy's importunities and went on his way The boy seized hold of the gun and was attempting to disarm M. Grandmoulin when the weapon went off, killing, the boy on che spot.

The dead boy's relatives soon appeared on the scene, and his brothers were on the point of avenging his death, when they were prevented by the father. M. Grandmoulin was arrested and handed over to the French consular authorities, who have opened an inquiry.

div.head: THE RODAH BRIDGES.
div.p: The rumour circulated by some of the local papers that the official inauguration of the two bridges connecting Old Cairo and Ghizeh with Rodah Island would take place this month, is altogether incorrect since the contract entered into with Messrs. Sir John Arrol & Co. in December, 1904, stipulates that the work is to be completed in 21 years, which date expires in Tune äext. By then the work by the contractors will be terminated, but as the Government will still have the approaches to make it s not expected that the inauguration can take place before some time in November
We are informed that a modification has been made in the footpaths of the bridges, which, instead of being wooden as originally intended, are to be of steel covered with cement or asphalte.

div.head: SUDAN COTTON RATES.
div.p: Great satisfaction has been caused, says the Sudan Times," by the decision of the Government to reduce the railway freight rates on Bidan cotton exported / via Halfa and Port Budan. This will, no doubt, encourage cultirators to extend their cotton cultivation as a large margin of profit can now be safely counted upon.

div.head: LORD CROMER'S SUPREMACY
div.p: The Aborigines Protection Society has begun to take Egypt under its protecting wing, and the secretary of that institution, Mr H. R Fox Bourne, announces that it is proposed to issue at intervals in the course of the next few months, a series of pamphlets under the general title of "Lord Cromer's Supremacy," and in furtherance of reforms for which the need was briefly indicated in an earlier " pamphlet entitled Egypt under British Control'. Among the natters which will probably be dealt with -re :- Military Control, Finance, Administration of Justice, Education, Public Works, Municipal Institutions, and the Capitulations

The first number of these notes on Egyptian affairs is to hand. The accuracy of this pamphlet, which is evidently written by a man who is ignorant of the country, may be gauged From the following paragraph with which it concludes :-"Every on, acquainted with the inner life of the Egyptians is aware of their remarkable freedom from the bigotry usually assigned to professors of the Moslem faith, and, however strongly and reasonably they may object to the unworthy concomitants of British rule, of their marked preference of that rule, with all its defects, to the Turkish rule from which they have been delivered. All they ask is that British rule shall be purged of the abuses that so grievously lessen its value to them."

div.head: PERSONAL, AND SOCIAL.
div.p: Sir Rudolph Baron von Slatin: Pasha, Inspector General of the Sudan, will probably visit the Dongola province in the course of a week, prior to the tour of inspection which the Governor General proposes to make in that province in the latter part of this month.
Count Koziebrodski has proceeded on the White Nile for a hunting trip as far as Kodok Count Koziebrodski proposes to reach Løb on a visit to the Catholic Mission station at that place.
M. Scotides, Hellenic Consul General, has gone to Khartoum in connection, with the establishment of a Greek consulate for the Sudan.

Signor de Martino, late Governor of Ery. threa, passed through Port Said a day or two ago on his way to meet his successor, the Mar: quis Salvago-Ruggi, late Italian Minister in Cairo, for the purpose of handing over his post.
Mr Mellwraith, the Judicial Adviser, is expected to return to Cairo on the 18th inst., on the conclusion of his inspection in Lower Egypt.

The death is announced, at Lucerne, of Mr. Arthur Buck Kitchener, F.G.S., brother of General Viscount Kitchener, from pneumonia. " Originally it had been intended that he should join the Royal Navy, but his bent was towards the study of mineralogy and mining engineering, and this, combined with a love of travel, led to his traversing nearly every part of the globe, and frequently visiting places where a white man is rarely seen. Although a bold and fearless traveller, he possessed a tact and an inherent kindness of disposition which saved him from many dangers incident to his journey. ings. His reports on the geological conditions of the many countries and islands he visited have proved of great service. Mr. Arthur Kitchener married, in 1896, Edith, the second daughter of the late Mr. John Paterson, of Holland Park, W.
Lieut.-Col. H. M. Campbell, R. H. A., and Lieut. D.J. C. E. Sherlock, R. H. A., have been granted three months' leave of absence, the latter with permission to travel in Italy, Austria, and Russia.

Among the visitors at the Luxor Winter Palace are Sir John and Lady Evans, Countess Skamenzka, Capt. Trefusis, Sir Arthur Brand, Col Willan, Mme Paul Bert, Crooksbank Pasha and Mrs. "Crookshank, Mrs. Alfred Lambart, Miss Campion, M. end Mme Char. tran, etc.
The christening of Dr. N. Kalomiry's little son took place on Sunday. Mrs. Elias Protopapas was the Gor-mother and named him Phasdon.

The passengers by the train de luxe for Upper Egypt on Sunday were : Lady Lanesborough, Captain Gell, Mr. Hamilton, Mr. J.B. Deane, Mr. Legua, Miss Portal, Mr. Despa, Mr. Maurylety, Comte, de Pontarce, Mr. Wells.
A large number of visitors are staying at the Savoy Hotel, Luxor, including Professor and Mrs Parker, Rev. H. A. Caper, Rev. H. A. Raynes, Geimrath and Mrs. Riegner, etc.

div.head: THE UPPER NILE.
RIVER TRANSPORT.
div.p: Khartoum to Gondokoro 1 A few years sin This journey was one which carried with -All the hardships and discomforts attendant upon an expedition into a practically unknot and Indeed difficulties of the Sudd region with the uncertainties of obtaining a navigable waterway through the swamps, for many yes rendered the journey an impossibility. But since then a systematic effort has been made to combat the damning effects of the Sudd in upper reaches of the Nile, and to-day tl York begun by Major-Peake, R.E., almost in mediately after the fall of Omdarman, ar orought to its ultimate conclusion as late 904 by Lieut. Drury, R.N., and Mr. Pool 3 complete, and an uninterrupted waterway secured from Uganda to Khartoum. The possession of this 1,100 miles of water as a means of transport is, in view of the ever increasing prosperity of the Sudan, certain -ne of its most valuable assets.At the present day, with the notable exceptions of the transport of gum from Dueim, and that of ivory from the southern reaches There is perhaps but little revenue actually accruing from the transport of merchandise but as gradually the evils of under-population the rural districts are being overcome, and the value of the already rich provinces which border the Nile increase, so also will transport with its attendant revenue 'expand. That the land is well suited to the growth of cotton has been conclusively proved by experiment, and now that with the opening of the Port Sudan Railway one of the greatest obstacles to the growth of cotton as a financial undertaking has been removed, there is no reason why the Sudan should not in time yield a regular supply for the European markets The first essentials a quick and cheap mode of transport from the grower to the market. The journey from Gondokoro to Khartoum is accomplished under ordinary circumstances, in from 10 to 12 days, according to the strength of wind and stream.

At no place are there any, real difficulties in navigation, excepting only at the ford Abou Zeit, which lies a little to the south o Soz-Abou-Goma, and this is only unnavigable when a very exceptionally low Nile occurs l'he bed of the ford is composed of the hells of an oyster-like fish cemented together with the natural clay and roc! f the river bottom, and is extremely Difficult to remove, gun cotton and such explosives having practically no effect upon it while it is almost impossible to remove it by and labour.

It would certainly pay the Sudan Government to have a sufficient breadth of channel out to allow the passage of at least one steamer or a low Nile may occur when least expected, ad in such a case, under existing circ im the circumstances a steamer has to discharge her cargo tone end of the ford, and transfer it by shallow draught feluccas to the other. Apart from the expense resulting from such a lethod, it would be likely to cause serious disorganisation and delay, should there at ay time arise any trouble in the south necessitating the immediate dispatch of troops from headquarters ; and this point alone would surely be sufficient justification for the spense of the required excavation. Once remove this obstacle and an open waterway assured, at all states of the Nile, the tire distance between the Uganda. Protectorate and Khartoum. In the Bahr-el-Ghazal, transport is, and will necessarily remain, pendent on the flood.

The river is important, communicating as it pes directly with the headquarters of the ahr-el-Ghazal Province at Wan, through its ibutary the Sur River. The Sur formed, until cent years, simply part of the huge swamp which lies to the north of the Bahr-el-Ghazal. it owing to the untiring efforts of successive expeditions sent up each year to deal with it, the river is now open to transport for about three months of the year during flood, and it possible to transport, while the river is open, cumulated stores sufficient for the needs of e western portion of the province for the remaining nine months, while supplies for the st can at all times be sent through Shambe the Bahr-el-Gebel. During the summer months the Sur dries up almost completely while the Bahr-el-Ghazal itself has only sufficient water to enable steamers to traverse out two-thirds of its length..

The accumulation of sudd in the latter year offers difficulties not met with in the others, inasmuch as there is not sufficient force of current to carry away the vegetation to the White Nile oven when it has been loosened. Each steamer which goes up even during flood runs the risk of being delayed by sudd, but the cost of thoroughly clearing the river would be enormous, and would certainly not be justified, considering the small yield produce from the province at the present time.

Navigation on the Blue Nile is also, un unfortunately, dependent on the flood, as during six months of low water it is impossible to any but the smallest boats through the ro channels of shallow water which alone exist | At the time of the flood, steamers can present proceed only as far as Rosaires, it would require comparatively little lab I to blast a passage through the cataract wh | lies to the south, and there establish commu cation with Famica, the Sudanese station, the Abyssinian frontier, should this be deen necessary at a future time.

A railway is important, if not absolutely necessary to the proper development of Blue Nile provinces, and also a railway from Irrum to Kordofan would be of very gry advantage to the country, but a good a sufficient fleet on the Nile is what we must look to as a connecting link between the vast p vinces' to the south of the Egyptian Buda and the rail end at Khartoum North.

It is now some years since the Sudan Development Company sprang into existence a launched its boats upon the river, but though holding a substantial financial guarantee from the Government, there is at present, apparently no definition as to where the competition between the Government boats and the boe of the company begins and euds. This is in self deleterious to the best interests of the Sudan

It remains with the Government to decide in what manner the welfare of the count can be best served, either by the gradual reduction of their present cargo fleet, accor panied by a corre-ponding increase in that the private company, or in the running of the major portion of the river traffic on Governme lines. The country is as yet too young to profit any appreciable extent by competition on er lives, and too poor to support such competitic as the present.

Should it be the intention of the Government to work the commercial transport of the Nile itself, then the existing fleet is ur doubtedly insufficient, and no time should be lost, or money spared, in increasing it, until i is in a position to meet all reasonable demands If on the other hand the authorities decide that the demands of the country would be better supplied by private enterprise, then it is clear that their duty lies in forwarding the interests of any company they may sanction by withdrawing, to as great an extent as possible, the existing opposition.

div.head: EGYPTIAN UNIVERSITIES
div.p: A gentleman whom we described some years go as a French authority on English local government now deals with a 'widely different, utalso arid subject, in L enseignement, la Doctrine et la Vie dans les Universités musulmanes d Egypte (Paris: F. Alcan).M. Arminjon as become a professor in the Khedivial School Law at Cairo, and writes with patient learning on the subjects which his title exactly eşcribes. There is not in his volume a word mat is modern or can be tortured into any earing upon the Egyptian question, or even at of the relations between Islam and the uwers. The fact that the Egyptian training hooks attached to the Cairene mosques are, the author's opinion, the chief seats of Mohamedan learning and tradition is noteworthy. It would be.of interest to obtain statistics owing what number and proportion of the adents attached to them, most of whom beme Mullahs, are pilgrims from distant. parts the Mohammedan world within the Turkish d French dominions, or even from Morocco d Afghanistan. It has been playfully said at the Egyptian Government continues to subsidize two universities, existing side by side Cairo, of which one officially teaches that the sun goes round the world, while the other, with equal authority, proclaims the more usual modern view. ("The Athenaeum").

div.head: SEVERE WINTER WEATHER.
div.p: Larnach, 8th March.

The weather remains very cold and fitfi The Troodos range is clad in snow and snow fell in Nicosia last week, as also on the northern range of mountains. Altogether this has been the severest winter known in Cyprus for many years past. It has retarded the spring grow and damage has in pluces been caused to your plants by the cold winds and occasional fros

div.head: EMPLOYMENT OF PLOUGHS.
div.p: The cotton sowing season is now approaching and it is to be hoped that a welcome change to warmer climate conditions is not far o An increasing number of European ploug! are now at work in different parts of the Islar and, other conditions being favourable, cotto lands will no doubt benefit by the more thorough cultivation which those ploughe-should effect There is a marked increase in the demand for reaping machines, which appear to give great satisfaction wherever employed.

div.head: THE PRICE OF MEAT.
div.p: The price of meat this year has risen beyond all previous records. Fifteen copper piastres per oke (1/8d per 2 3/4 lbs.) has been no unusual pride to pay for mutton, and beef i nearly as much, and the quality of the joint is, of course, inferior to the best. In the massol district, where prices generally rule higher, the average price for beef was i November 14 piastres per oke and in December 18 piastres ; while mutton ranged about 1 piastres in November and 19 piastres in December, and lamb is said to have fetched 22 cp and even 24 cp. per oke. Eggs have for some time been sold at three for one piastre. Al these figures represent an immense rise upon average prices of only a year or two ago I this connection it is a matter for congratulation that a Bill is to be introduced into the Legislative Council prohibiting the slaughter sale or export of any young lambs weighing less than five okes dead weight Hitherto in the early months of every year the most diminutive lambs have been killed, and little other meat has been obtainable. Not only is the practice one of false economy on the part of the breeder but most unsatisfactory and expensive from the consumer's standpoint.

div.head: LEGISLATIVE COUNCIL.
div.p: The Legislative Council, having replied to the opening speech of His Excellency the High Commissioner, has got to work and appears to be making reasonable progress Among the more important subjects to which the reply draws attention may be named the inadequate pay of officials in view of the general rise in the cost of living ; it suggests that children should receive some instruction in the public elementary schools in matters relating to forestry ; it recommends the establishment of a practical agricultural school under the direction of the Agricultural Department and the teaching in the public elementary schools of subjects connected with agriculture ; it advocates that every facility be given by the Department to agriculturists to obtain useful and healthy plants and seeds and modern implements of husbandry; it makes various recommendations in regard to matters relating to the public health ; it urges . n increase to he Education Vote beyond the increase of €500 already granted ; it puts forward for the consideration of the Council the question of the abolition or commutation of the tithes ; and it submits that it is becoming urgently incumbent to make legislative provision for the administration of the property of the "Archiepiscopal See and for the election of an Archbishop

div.head: SMALLPOX EPIDEMIC.
div.p: The smallpox epidemic in the central Megaoria has, we are glad to learn, been practically checked. In a country like this where the ignorance of the villagers in matters pertaining to health and sanitation is supreme, the probability of the spread of any epidemic is somewhat serious, and the efforts of the medical authorities in keeping the cases of smallpox under control have been credible to hose immediately responsible.

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.
div.p: A NOVEL COMPETITION.

A sporting event of quite a novel character took place yesterday on the K.S.C. ground, Ar. F. Stout, an athlete of great renown having very pluckily undertaken to run twice around the racecourse over the jumps against a horse which had to go round four times. The horse belonged to Major Gillson, and is called sloe Gin. The distance round the course is 1 mile, 1 furlong. Odds were laid on Mr. Stout, as much as 3 to 1 by some sportsmen, but they were disappointed. Sloe Gin, never putting a foot wrong and beautifully ridden by the jockey Johnson, won comfortably, the time being 13 minutes. Mr. Stout was handicapped by a bad cold and stopped three furlongs from ume, after being passed by the horse. His est time whilst training was 13 min: 16 sec., which is a marvellous performance. considering the nature of the ground and the jumps. There as quite a large gathering to witness the race.
The squash racquets tournament will commco on the 20th inst.

div.head: GHARBIEH LAND COMPANY.
INTERESTING EXCURSION TO ESTATE
div.p: On Thursday night a large number of gentlemen were invited to inspect the Gharbie Land Company's property at Ras-el-Khalig One sleeping and one dining car were reserved for their use and the party, after dining oi the train, spent the night on the former car I whiệh was shunted after arrival at Mansourah

After breakfast on Friday morning the train left for Ras-el-Khalig, arriving shortly after 8 a.m. Trolleys drawn by mules conveyed the visitors thence to Kafr El-Wastani, halts being made on the way to enable them to inspect the steam cultivator and the pumping station On arrival at Kafr-el-Wastani the visitor partook of light refreshment at Mr. Hender son's bungalow_one of Messrs. Humphrey portable houses---and then returned to Rasel Khalig by trolley. On the way back a muk bolted, all but causing a collision between two of the ears, but no harm was done, though two or three of the passengers risked nasty falls in jumping to avoid being caught by the car. Lunch at Ras el-Khalig followed, when M. Rolin proposed the health of the officials of the Gharbieh Land Company in a well-chosen speech, Mr. Hood rèplying. Piot, Bey then proposed the health of the company, which was drunk with enthusiasm. Lunch and toasts over, the train steamed to Sawalim, where the party, mounted on donkeys, visited the -site of a new steam pump on the bank of the Damiętta branch of the Nile. All then returned by train to Mansourah, where first-class carriages had been reserved for the party, which finally reached Cairo, villa Tantah, late on Friday night after a most interesting and comfortable trip, ably managed by Colonel Sylmer, to whom the thanks of the party are due.

The area of the Gharbieh Land Company's estates åt Ras-el-n balig amounts to nearly 8,700 feddans, of which 2,000 have already been washed and are under cultivation, while e 5,000 feddans more have been drained and will - shortly be yielding excellent crops. Houses, stores, and stables have been built, 16 kilometres of trolley line laid down, and a very complete mechanical installation supplied, including three new syphons, and a 14-inch pump. Good work this for a year's occupation.

Among the party were Chakour Pasha, Col Aylmer, Dr Ekins, Mr. Pearson, Mr. McQueen, M. Brierre, M Rolin M. Van der Bosche, General Amandie, Mr. Allen and Mr.' B. Alderson, Piot Bey, Milhem Bey Shakour, Tewfik Bey Kahil, Mr. Sibbala M. Arminjon, Abd el Hamid Bey Abaza M. Jean Eid, Wassif Bey, and several representatives of the Press.

div.head: UNFORGOTTEN."
div.p: I found the Persian rose and kiss'd the leaves That crown'd you once a queen of fantasies, | When Philomel that night within the nest Sat silent while you sang and thought it best Your plaintive notes like hers the lost to : [speech]

Thrill'd through the heart—a music' none could (teach, Now memory echoes back—the song of each ! The Minaret stands fair against the sky, Its blue outlining marble tracery, The pathway is the same, but not to me, Yet living buds adorn that scented tree. There is another spot with roses set, Where sweeps a strain of passionate regret. Ah! would you say to both : forget I forget I

How vain the thought !' the nightingale still . [sings The throes of love, its sweet and bitter things, Between tall pains the pale stars shine again, Beyond, is Paradise without life's pain, In fadeless gardens, with a soul refresh'd You walk along, a silent timid guest Here sorrow is confusion—there 'tis blest!
VIOLET DE MALORTIE.
WRENCE

div.head: MOSLEMS AND THE CALIPH.
div.p: To the EDITOR OF THE "BGYPTIAN GAZETTE."

Dear Sir, - In the issue of the "Egyptian Gazette" of the 10th October there appeared an article signed "Spectator," wherein the writer declares that the British Government has always borne the Moslems under its rule special feelings of affection, and he takes pride in the good that the British have done to the Moslems of India and Egypt But be conolades his article with the allegation that the Sultan is the bitterest foe of Great Britain, and with other allegations of an analogous nature. | Such statements seem to me to call fortki some elucidative, not to say corrective, remarks, I will therefore inform this "Spectator" ;| First, that it would have behoved him better | to frankly sign his article and not stand behind a pseudonym.

Secondly, that he is under a gross misapprehension in regard to his tabólief of our sovereign Sultan being the sworn foe of Great Britain. We care indeed to inform him, and others of the same frame of mind,.that our Sultan is an enemy to nobody but rather a friend of Great Britain and of all the nations, His August Majesty is: a noble and shored personage distinguished by generosity of hand and heart, and adorned by the noblest qualities. He is at the same time clement and merciful, and just and powerful, far from evil and harm of any kind. True' civilization and enlightened education constitute the elements of his moral self. He is a faithful follower of the law of our lord Mohamed, the prophet of AllHah, and of the principles of the Coran. He. therefore whose qualities are such cannot be an enemy of anybody. This mistaken idea, however, may have originated in the impolicy of a certain class of England's statesmen, but such regrettable illusions will disappear, when these very statesmen shall pursue the true policy of a friendly rapprochement with his Majesty.

I do not wish to enter here into any discussion as to what the writer of the article under review says respecting the good treatment by the English of the Moslems of India and Egypt, but I may inform him for his edification that were the English to cast the Moslems of India and Egypt into the pure gold of prosperity and material welfare and to cause the times to weave for them garments of milk" and yet oppose our sovereign the Sultan their Caliph, all this would go in vain.

Be it known to all the nations that the Sultan Al Ghazi Abdul Hamid Khan is known to all the Moslems in the different quarters of the globe as the Caliph of Allah and the Caliph of His Prophet. He has occupied the throne of the Moslem Caliphate for over 32 years now, a long reign spent in strenuous endeavour and sacrifice of mental and bodily rest for the raising still higher of the beacon of enlightenment and progress in his great Ottoman dominious. Wherefore all his subjects, be they Moslems or Christians, natives or foreigners, have come to bear his Majesty & great love, and to pray for the preservation of his reign to the end of time.

Thus do we find also our Egyptians true and loyal to his Majesty and the Moslems admire in them this love and devotion and this faithful allegiance to our Sultan who is indeed their Sultan. We the Moslems: indeed take pride in their meal and patriotism, and lavish upon them every praise, asking Allah to prosper them and guard them by his Mercy and Providence. -

Be it known also that it is incumbent on us Moslems counting among, our vast ranks the Sherifs of Mecca, the great Emira and Chief. Pains of the Arabs, the Turks, Arnauta, Kurds and others, it is incumbent on us to offer our submission and allegiance at all times to our Sovereign Caliph the Sultan Al Ghazi Abdul Hamid Khan.
ABDUL-KADER EL-DANA, Beyrout Feb. 12..

Ogwanieh,' leaving Alexandria on March 14th and 281b, will follow a special fa-t itinerary, reaching Piræus (Athen) in 80 hours, Smyrna in 47 hours, and Constantinople in 74 hours, in connection with ihe Oriental, Railways daily express service for Vienna, Berlin, Parks and London. | Special arrangements will be made for part of the 7.30-a.m. ' Express train from Cairo to run direct alongside.

This vessel is most luxuriously appointed, with accommodation (mostly in 2.berth cabin on deck, for 142 first class amida bips and 70 Second class aft. div.head: Supplement Commercial et Financier DE " L'EGYPTIAN GAZETTE".
div.p: Le Supplément Commercial et Financier de l'Egyptian Gazette" paraît chaque Samedi à midi, de façon à pouvoir être expédié par le paquebot autrichien. Il contient des ret 068 complètes et impartiales de coton, des graines De coton, et du marboré dos valeurs; les dernières statistiques jusqu'à la veil e de sa publi. tation : des tableaux des fluctuations de la f I place et les copies des dépêches officielles envoyées à la Liverpool Cotton Association, etc etc L'abonnement pour une année en Egypte hoogte 1 L.E. y compris les frais de poste ; pour l'étranger 10 P.T. de port en AUR.

"L'argent est toujours très recherché ici par suite des demaúdes de New York, et le temps de l'escompte libre se maintient à 4 7/8 pour cent. Aussi le Stock Bobinage BQ ressort-i d'ang tension monétaire qui se prolonge au-delà des limites de temps prévues. On s'attend toutefois à une amélioration dans le courant de La semaine prochaine, car âne détente est considérée comme certaine. L3 marché monétair est, en effet, appelé à bénéficier de la nouvelle réforme judiciaire votée au Sénat américain, ce qui permettra au secrétaire du Trésor de mettre de fortes sommes à la disposition des Banques."

div.head: NOTICE.
div.p: The Associated Cotton Ginners of Ezyp Limited offer for sale a plot of building lanc of about 16,000 square metres, at Mansourab rae Kuantaret Kafr el Badamas (formerly the Planta Usine) of which the buyer will take possession in November 197. For all partition ats apply to the Head office : Old Bourre-tree (Central Buildings) Alexandria ; or to the Usine de la Soolotó ex Planta, Mansourab.

div.head: Commercial & Financial Supplement OF THE " Egyptian Gazette."
div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, ootton seed, and stock and share market, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egyptfor abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). For Further particulars apply to the Manager the Egyptian Gazette."

Cours de l'Association des Courtiers en Marchand. 6h. p.m.
REMARQUES
COTON-Nouvelle recolte: Demandee, mais addaires restreintes, faute de vendeurs. Cours tres fermes.

Recolte nxxmelle: Eu commerve a achere dans l'aores-midi et cela a contribue a raffermir les cours. En cloture nous acons au une legere reaction, mais quand meme nous resions en benefice de 7/82 sur la coture de 1 heure.
Dans la matinee prix plus haus pour mars talarie 12 3.32 a -/-; plus bas pour mars 12 1/16 a -/-. Dans l'apres-midi prix plus haus pour mars 12 3 8 a -/-; plus has pour mars 12 7/32 a -/-.

REMARQUES
Cotons: Nouvelle récolte.—Le novembre a ouvert à 14 15/16 sous l'impression de la clôture d'Amérique et ne tarde même pas à fléchir à 14 7/8, mais il se raffermit de nouveau. Affaires claisemées.
Récolte actuelle. —Juillet a débuté à 14 5/16 et reste soutenu. Marché peu animé.
Grains de coton: Nouvelle récolte.— Sans affaires importante; quand même les cours sont bien tenus.
Récolte actuelle.—Juillet a obtenu P.T. 58 ¾ à l'ouverture.
Fèves-Saidi: Nouvelle récolte.—Marché nul.
